240 With patient Hope unmov'd their Station keep,
241 Till from the secret Chambers of the Deep
242 Laden with Spoils the Diver mounts again,
243 Nor can the Surface reach with all his Pain.
244 By wonted Arts he strives himself to raise,
245 But o'er his Head th' unwelcome Pressure stays.
246 Poiz'd on the Floods the Cieling hangs above,
247 No human Force the vaulted Roof can move.
248 Kept back from look'd-for Day the Mortal grieves,
249 In vain the pressing Lid his Shoulder heaves;
250 His weaker Trust the stubborn Weight withstands,
251 And backward sinks him down to lowest Sands.
[Page 70]
252 If he swims forward, and the Surface leaves,
253 The subtle Fish the vain Attempt perceives;
254 Still hangs aloof, and o'er his pensive Head
255 The Shades unwish'd their gloomy Covert spread.
256 Till weary'd Arms their toilsome Work refuse,
257 But faintly strike, and catch the yielding Ooze.
258 As when the falling Lid with quick Surprize
259 Close in the Trap confines th' unwary Mice,
260 Immur'd they search the concave Prison round,
261 Hurry despairing, and impatient bound;
262 As well they might the fruitless Labour cease,
263 No friendly Gap affords a kind Release;
264 Till wanton Boys the trembling Wretch relieve,
265 Free from Confinement, but of Life bereave.
266 Such is the Toil, when vent'rous Divers meet
267 The floating Roof, and push the pressing Weight.
268 Stretcht on the wat'ry Plain unmov'd it lies,
269 And open Air, and lightsome Day denies:
270 Till swallow'd Waves an easy Passage find,
271 And in it's latest Breath Life mingles with the Wind.
272 Thus proud of her Success the spreading Ray
273 By Stratagem obtains the noblest Prey.
274 As in some mossy Cave the Fishing Swain
275 At Leisure sits, and views the wavy Main,
[Page 71]
276 Oft he beholds how Crabs their Watches keep,
277 And wait the Motions of the shelly Heap.
278 Oysters around on cliffy Peaks are hung,
279 To rocky Beds, and cranny'd Jettings clung.
280 Immur'd they lie close in the pearly Shell,
281 But cannot long their juicy Stores conceal;
282 Moisture they seek, and then no longer hid
283 Loosen'd they gape, and heave the upper Lid.
284 The Crab observes, and to the sandy Mounds,
285 Where polish'd Stones the whirling Eddy rounds,
286 He busy creeps along, with forked Claws
287 From the loose Heap the flinty Pebble draws.
288 Thus burden'd, silent to the Oyster steals,
289 And wedges fast the Stone between the Shells.
290 Divided thus no more the Parts are clos'd,
291 But all the luscious Sweets must lie expos'd.
292 By prosp'rous Fraud he gains the envy'd Meal,
293 And drags the panting Captive from his Cell.
294 The prickly Star creeps on with like Deceit,
295 To force the Oyster from his close Retreat.
296 When gaping Lids their widen'd Void display,
297 The watchful Star thrusts in a pointed Ray,
298 Of all its Treasure spoils the rifled Case;
299 And empty Shells the sandy Hillocks grace.
[Page 72]
300 In clouded Depths below the Nacre hides,
301 And thro' the silent Paths obscurely glides;
302 A stupid Wretch, and void of thoughtful Care,
303 He forms no Bait, nor lays the tempting Snare.
304 But the dull Sluggard boasts a kinder Friend,
305 Whose busy Eyes the coming Prey attend.
306 One Room contains them; and the Partners dwell
307 Beneath the Convex of one sloping Shell.
308 Deep in the wat'ry Vast the Comrades rove,
309 And mutual Int'rest binds their constant Love.
310 That wiser Friend the lucky Juncture tells,
311 When in the Circuit of his gaping Shells
312 Fish wand'ring enter; then the bearded Guide
313 Warns the dull Mate, and pricks his tender Side.
314 He knows the Hint, nor at the Treatment grieves,
315 But hugs th' Advantage, and the Pain forgives.
316 His closing Shells the Nacre sudden joyns.
317 And 'twixt the pressing Sides his Prey confines.
318 Thus fed by mutual Aid, the friendly Pair
319 Divide their Gains, and all the Plunder share.
320 Men are not all with equal Knowledge blest;
321 Man differs more from Man, than Man from Beast.
322 The prudent Mind by studious Labour taught
323 Wise Schemes pursues, and fines the ruder Draught.
[Page 73]
324 While blockish Mortals doze their Hours away,
325 Or give to brutal Joys the cheated Day.
326 Like them the gliding Shoals, that gladsome rove
327 O'er liquid Fields, and Sea-green Pastures love,
328 Are not with equal Shares of Wit endow'd;
329 Heav'n has unlike the partial Gift bestow'd.
330 Some on the Cares of future Life intent
331 Consult their Welfare, and their Ills prevent;
332 While worthless Numbers take their giddy Way,
333 Cumber the Seas, and only serve for Prey.
334 Hear now th' instructive Song, ye thoughtless Wights,
335 Wedded to Sense, and fixt on mean Delights.
336 The Sea's dull Sleeper bids, that shortliv'd Fish,
337 In Time to curb your yet unbounded Wish.
338 Think on his Conduct, and remark his Fate,
339 And in th' insatiate Fish the Glutton hate.
340 In sensual Joys he squanders Life away,
341 Revels the Night, and slumbers out the Day.
342 Fixt backward on his Head the rolling Eyes
343 Look up, and might behold the distant Skies;
344 But the curst Sluggard flies the chearful Ray,
345 And in long Slumbers skreens the hated Day.
346 Midst these his Mouth it's spacious Chasm displays,
347 And the lewd Call of Hunger's Wish obeys.
[Page 74]
348 All the bright gladsome Hours he sullen Sleeps,
349 Battens on Sands, or hides in slimy Heaps;
350 Hence call'd the Ocean-Owl, like Owls afraid
351 Of brighten'd Skies, and fond of gloomy Shade.
352 When the brown Dusk on slumb'ring Waters broods,
353 And midnight Breezes rock the murm'ring Floods,
354 When darken'd Billows sound with deeper Roar,
355 Rouz'd from Repose he quits the weedy Shore:
356 Hunger's loud Call bids wake from slothful Ease,
357 And search th' unempty'd Stores of plenteous Seas.
358 But the lewd Wretch of ready Meals possest
359 Unsated gluts, when full begins the Feast,
360 Feeds on, in midst of Plenty most accurst,
361 Till the cram'd Paunch o'er-fill'd with Pressure burst.
362 O'er-charg'd with Food the pamper'd Glutton lies,
363 Motion and Strength th' unwieldy Load denies;
364 Till Death's last Pains to fatal Treats succeed,
365 And hov'ring Shades the darken'd Eyes o'er-spread.
366 If with kind Hand you give the Glutton Meat,
367 He rav'nous feeds, and will unweary'd eat,
368 Till his swoln Maw with useless Lumber stow'd
369 Bursting at length discharge the nauseous Load.
370 Like him luxurious Men their Vigour wast,
371 The Throat to tickle, and indulge the Tast.
[Page 75]
372 But future Pain the lawless Joy begets,
373 A Train of Ills succeeds the transient Sweets.
374 While ill-tim'd Feasts and midnight Revels please,
375 Continu'd Meals improve the hid Disease,
376 To Poyson turn the undigested Food,
377 And treasure up their Ills in tainted Blood.
378 From cruder Meats unactive Vapours rise,
379 The Spirits clog, and cloud the languid Eyes.
380 Ridges of Fat the manly Form disgrace,
381 And bloated Veins enlarge the purpled Face.
382 Reason's weak Light from noisome Fumes retires,
383 And too much Fewel choaks the smother'd Fires.
384 Men too unwise let go the slacken'd Rein,
385 But they who think will lewd Desires restrain,
386 Check the Emotion, and the Wish control,
387 And shun the Fate of the luxurious Owl.
388 Foresight and Art the prickly Urchins boast,
389 To keep the Seas, and shun the rocky Coast.
390 When teeming Clouds the infant Tempest form,
391 And whisp'ring Winds concert the future Storm,
392 They careful fear, lest forc'd to distant Lands
393 They dash on Rocks, or bulge on rising Sands.
394 Too light themselves their Motions to control
395 When the tenth Billows o'er their Fellows roll,
[Page 76]
396 They Ballast seek, with busy Eyes explore
397 The various Pebbles of the winding Shore,
398 Choose out the Stone, and with that steady Weight
399 Fixt on their Backs, the raging Waters meet.
400 Thus poiz'd they careless keep their destin'd Way,
401 Nor the rude Shock of thwarting Floods obey.
402 All Fishers know the changing Prekes Deceit
403 How clung to Rocks, when coming Dangers threat,
404 New Forms they take, and wear a borrow'd Dress,
405 Mock the true Stone, and Colours well express.
406 Now o'er their liken'd Parts the Limners spread
407 A mossy Green, or streak with dusky Red;
408 On their soft Skin now whitish Marl imprint,
409 Or raise the clouded Azure of the Flint:
410 As the Rock looks, they take a diff'rent Stain,
411 Dapple with Grey, or branch the livid Vein.
412 Nor scaly Foes, nor Fishers curious Eyes
413 Perceive the Cheat, or find the false Disguise.
414 Thus they conceal'd the dreaded Danger shun,
415 By borrow'd Shapes obscur'd, and lost in seeming Stone.
416 But when with near Approach the weaker Prey
417 Invites, her waning Colours all decay;
418 No Vizard then, or mimick Form they seek;
419 Vig'rous they quit the Rock, and own the real Preke.
[Page 77]
420 When wint'ry Skies o'er the black Ocean frown,
421 And Clouds hang low with ripen'd Storms o'ergrown,
422 Close in the Shelter of some vaulted Cave
423 The soft-skin'd Prekes their porous Bodies save.
424 But forc'd by Want, while rougher Seas they dread,
425 On their own Feet necessitous are fed.
426 But when returning Spring serenes the Skies,
427 Nature the growing Parts anew supplies.
428 Again on breezy Sands the Roamers creep,
429 Twine to the Rocks, or paddle in the Deep.
430 Doubtless the God, whose Will commands the Seas,
431 Whom liquid Worlds, and wat'ry Natives please,
432 Had taught the Fish by tedious Wants opprest
433 Life to preserve, and be himself the Feast.
434 Thus, when the Clouds their snowy Burden drop,
435 And rising Heaps improve the Mountain's Top,
436 When Earth scarce feels the Sun's obliquer Beams,
437 And creeping Ice confines the lessen'd Streams,
438 The rough-clad Bear declines the rig'rous Day,
439 Hides in his Den, nor hunts abroad for Prey:
440 Sullen he lays him down, with busy Toil
441 Licks his large Feet, and sucks the fat'ning Oil.
442 Thus fed with poor Repast the Savage lives,
443 Till with fresh Sap the wither'd Plant revives,
[Page 78]
444 Till lengthen'd Days the Bands of Winter loose,
445 And Warmth untwists the Threads of soften'd Snows.
446 Then he to Woods returns, with tender Feet
447 Roams thro' the Brakes, and seeks the wonted Treat;
448 Slain Beasts devours, or climbs the rifted Tree,
449 And steals the Labours of the painful Bee.
450 In Wars alternate, with embitter'd Rage,
451 The Lobster, Lamprey, and the Preke engage.
452 Mutual their Fate, reciprocal the Wound;
453 By Turns they kill, and scatter Deaths around.
454 Each to the other is a grateful Feast,
455 Successively they treat th' unwelcome Guest.
456 Antipathy's entail'd; the future Breed
457 Must to hereditary Hate succeed.
458 While sportive Breezes fan the gentler Wave,
459 From the moist Crannies, or the winding Cave
460 Roaming abroad for Prey, the Lamprey sees
461 Where sandy Walks the lazy Creeper please.
462 Rapt with glad Hopes she feeds her wistful Eyes,
463 And all her Strength the finless Glider tries.
464 Conscious the Preke the curling Eddy fears,
465 Now from the rising Beach he list'ning hears
466 The rolling Floods, now shudd'ring looks around,
467 When troubled Waves with nearer Murmurs sound.
[Page 79]
468 The joyful Lamprey winds along the Flood,
469 And in glad Thought enjoys the coming Food:
470 Bounding she mounts all eager on the Chace;
471 Nor can the crawling Preke's too heavy Pace
472 Escape her Rage; He must unwilling try
473 War's doubtful Chance, and with hard Doom comply.
474 Born on high Waves the slipp'ry Foe commands
475 The nearer Shore, and darts on yielding Sands.
476 No Time to fly, no Hopes of coming Aid,
477 While murd'rous Teeth his tender Flesh invade.
478 Forc'd to the Fight, the Preke despairing strives,
479 All Postures shows, and various Schemes contrives.
480 Now on her Back his twining Tendrills play,
481 Now grasp her Sides, or force their heedless Way
482 Down her wide Throat, now round her Tail they fold,
483 To force her back, and break the fasten'd hold.
484 All Parts in vain are try'd; her slipp'ry Train
485 Eludes his Touch, and mocks the fruitless Pain.
486 So when contending Wrestlers twine around
487 In close Embrace, and beat the trampled Ground,
488 Now wreath their oily Limbs, now firmly stand,
489 And grasp the adverse Arm with dusty Hand;
490 Their cautious Feet incessant tread the Round,
491 Meet in rude Shock, and undistinguish'd sound;
[Page 80]
492 With various Shifts each others Skill perplex,
493 While Sweat in briny Streams flows down the Cheeks.
494 Like them the Preke his supple Members plies,
495 But less indulgent Fate Success denies.
496 Piteous the Scene, when mangled Parts employ
497 Remorseless Teeth, and give the cruel Joy.
498 Along the Sands the panting Pieces reek,
499 And ev'n in Death a Shelter seem to seek.
500 So when the Stag breaths on the guilty Heaps,
501 Where hid from Cold the wily Serpent sleeps,
502 That wond'rous Spell will rouze the crested Snake,
503 Forc'd from the Covert of the inmost Brake.
504 Angry he comes, high on his Folds uprears
505 His speckled Form, and hides his secret Fears.
506 Resolv'd the Stag his fixt Design pursues,
507 Gripes fast the Wretch, and gives the killing Bruise.
508 The Snake impatient winds his twisted Train,
509 And knotted Wreaths express the wringing Pain.
510 Now round the Stag's branch'd Horns he curling twines,
511 Now on his Neck the glossy Circle shines.
512 The Stag unmov'd the restless Struggler tears,
513 While greenish Stain the drooping Flow'ret smears.
514 Scatter'd around the mangled Gobbets fall,
515 And wriggling o'er the blasted Herbage crawl.
[Page 81]
516 Nor can the Preke by usual Arts escape,
517 And hide in borrow'd Forms the Fishy Shape.
518 All are besides deceiv'd; to her alone
519 Whom most he dreads his Artifice is known;
520 Her curious Thought the mimick Secret learns,
521 And painted Show from real Stone discerns.
522 With scornful Smile the Lamprey seems to speak,
523 And thus insults the Colour-changing Preke.
524 "Vain Trifler, can you hope by false Disguise
525 " T' elude my Wish, and cheat observing Eyes?
526 "Since you so well express the rocky Hue,
527 " If you'd be safer, take its Hardness too.
528 "By potent Charms the cleaving Stone divide,
529 " Enter within and there securely hide;
530 "Or let the Rock it's craggy Summit bend,
531 " Incline the Roof, and skreen the liken'd Friend.
532 "But since in changing Forms you vainly pride,
533 " Learn Wretch in meaner Cunning to confide.
534 Thus said, her spiral Circles on she bears,
535 And from the Rock the Preke relentless tears.
536 He, tho' no more his wonted Frauds deceive,
537 Hangs to the Cliff, nor will the Jetting leave.
538 When other Parts are lost, the branching Feet
539 Maintain their Hold, and grasp the rocky Seat.
[Page 82]
540 So when sack'd Towns to hostile Fury yield,
541 And mournful Streets with slaughter'd Heaps are fill'd,
542 The raving Mother strains with close Embrace
543 Her darling Babe, and hides his little Face:
544 The Parent's Neck his clinging Arms enfold;
545 Fear gives him Strength, and knits the firmer Hold.
546 Nor can the Plund'rers Rage with impious Hands
547 Divide the Pair, and loose their mutual Bands.
548 The Dame, midst the wild Transports of Despair,
549 Still clasps her weeping Babe, and minds her latest Care.
550 With Conquest flush'd new Wars the Lamprey breaths,
551 In prouder State her silver Volumes wreaths:
552 But urg'd by partial Hopes, and vain Conceit,
553 In her last Duel will the Lobster meet.
554 The well-arm'd Lobster clad in dusky Mail,
555 Nor fears her pointed Teeth, nor winding Tail.
556 Close by the Cave, where in the silent Shade
557 The feasted Lamprey sinks her easy Head,
558 He shakes his bearded Front, with Scorn extends
559 His wrinkled Horns, and thus the Challenge sends.
560 As, when two adverse Hosts encamp'd delay
561 The destin'd Fight, and wait the coming Day,
562 Impatient of Repose, some bolder Chief
563 Regrets lost Time, and feeds his inward Grief,
[Page 83]
564 Braces his Cuirass on, and grasps his Arms;
565 Thus dreadful pleases, and with Terrour charms:
566 Erect he walks, and waves his plumed Crest,
567 To Action calls, and blames inglorious Rest.
568 With taunting Language, and disdainful Eyes
569 The boldest Champion to the Plain defies.
570 While adverse Troops the haughty Menace hear,
571 Nor will the hostile Youth such Insult bear;
572 With Shame he reddens, and with Anger burns,
573 Accepts the Challenge, and the Scorn returns.
574 So from her inmost Cave, with proud Disdain,
575 The soft Sea-Lamprey spreads her wavy Train:
576 Enrag'd she comes, darts sudden from her Cell,
577 Seizes the Foe, and fixes on the Shell.
578 But vainly weary'd with successless Toil
579 From the hard Crust the baffled Teeth recoil.
580 No Entrance there the blunted Weapons find,
581 No Pressure leaves th' indented Mark behind.
582 At length provok'd the bearded Lobster ends
583 Unequal Strife, his forked Claw extends,
584 Pinches with rigid Force her yielding Sides,
585 Drives back the Blood, and all the Mass divides.
586 The Parts all bruis'd in racking Torture swell,
587 And languid Spots declining Vigour tell.
[Page 84]
588 By cruel Gripe the passive Wretch comprest
589 Twines up her Tail, and rears her shining Breast.
590 No Rest the Lobster gives, nor quits his hold;
591 In vain her spiry Wreaths their Circles fold.
592 Restless she moves, nor can her Pains conceal,
593 Clings to her Foe, and hugs the pointed Shell.
594 The piercing Lancets prick each tender Vein,
595 And purple Drops her beauteous Yellow stain:
596 She vainly striving but augments her Pain.
597 O'er his rough Back she twists the fatal Round,
598 Tears her soft Skin, and gives her self the Wound.
599 As when the captive Pard to bloody Sights,
600 And barb'rous Sports the gazing Throng invites,
601 The Champion, who the gawdy Sylvan dares,
602 First by rude Din the sullen Beast prepares.
603 Grimly he looks, and with malicious Leer
604 Grins at the Crowd, and mocks the shining Spear.
605 His unsheath'd Paws their pointed Fangs expose,
606 And wrinkled Lips exert their dreadful Rows.
607 Foolish he gapes, and with wide Mouth expects
608 As the bold Youth his well-aim'd Blow directs.
609 While grinning Jaws their open Void display,
610 Down the flung Spear takes swift it's destin'd Way.
[Page 85]
611 The yawning Beast a ready Passage gives,
612 And sheath'd within his Throat the whizzing Steel receives.
613 Th' imprudent Lamprey, urg'd by fierce Despite,
614 Thus aids the Foe, and tries the fruitless Bite.
615 While shelly Crusts the dusky Chief befriend,
616 And from rude Touch the tender Parts defend.
617 Madded with Pain, and crush'd by meeting Claws,
618 On the firm Plate the fond Sea-Lamprey gnaws:
619 Nor fears the rising Spikes that closely set
620 O'er the hard Shell their pointed Terrours threat:
621 But twines her Body round the sharpen'd Rows,
622 And the deep mortal Wounds to heedless Passion owes.
623 Such is the Combat, when in lone Retreats
624 Of silent Woods the crested Serpent meets
625 The Urchin's secret Track: by Nature they
626 The fierce Impulse of mutual Hate obey.
627 Approaching War the Urchin soon perceives,
628 And hears the distant Rustle of the Leaves.
629 Close in her own Embrace she shelter'd hides,
630 Contracts her Feet, and rounds her prickly Sides:
631 From ev'ry Part the thorny Bristles rise;
632 And thus enwrapt, unmov'd the Urchin lies.
[Page 86]
633 The rushing Serpent frights the Insect Race,
634 Shakes the low Boughs, and bends the spiry Grass;
635 Scornful he seizes midst the platted Brakes
636 The rounding Ball, and furious Onset makes;
637 With angry Jaws th' ungrateful Morsel chews,
638 While the safe Urchin mocks his weaker Bruise.
639 Enrag'd the Foe exerts his utmost Strength,
640 Draws in his Train, and twines his shorten'd Length.
641 Resolv'd he curls, and with a rough Embrace
642 Squeezes the Ball, and binds the prickly Case.
643 While oft the Urchin turns, and rolling gives
644 Unnumber'd Wounds; the tortur'd Serpent grieves.
645 Lost in his glossy Slough, and speckled Side,
646 Their sharpen'd Tops the piercing Needles hide.
647 Black venom'd Gore drops from the frothing Wound,
648 Hangs on the drooping Herb, and stains the blasted Ground.
649 Racking the Pain, but firm the Serpent holds,
650 And hides the Urchin in his mazy Folds.
651 Nor, fasten'd thus, could he uncurl again
652 His twisted Spires, or stretch his lengthen'd Train,
653 Gaunch'd on the Tenters of the prickly Beast;
654 Till dying both are from their Pains releast.
[Page 87]
655 But oft the Urchin, by the Serpent bruis'd,
656 Escapes with Hurt, and from the Prison loos'd
657 Creeps weaken'd o'er the Bank with sickly Pace,
658 And his sore Limbs enwraps in ranker Grass:
659 While fleshy Trophies on his Sides are born,
660 And all his prickly Back the gawdy Spoils adorn.
661 Like is th' Event of the unkind Embrace,
662 When the Sea-Lamprey hugs the shelly Case;
663 Wounds to her self by thoughtless Rage she gives,
664 She dies; and none the wilful Murder grieves.
665 But tho' firm Mail the vig'rous Lobster shields,
666 Yet to the slow the tender Preke he yields.
667 Beneath the Rock, where eating Eddies round
668 The shelving Cave, and plain in murm'ring Sound,
669 As void of Care the bearded Lobster lies,
670 The crawling Preke hasts to the destin'd Prize.
671 Behind with wary Steps he softly creeps,
672 And on the sounding Armour sudden leaps;
673 Spreads all his knotty Arms; they close entwin'd
674 The dusky Shell with painful Pressure bind,
675 With stubborn Squeeze the tortur'd Parts constrain,
676 And with firm Braces fix the rounding Chain.
677 His straighten'd Jaws the throttling Ties compress,
678 Dam up the Way, and make the Channel less.
[Page 88]
679 His Mouth chok'd up no flitting Blast receives,
680 Nor to the airy Stream the wonted Passage gives.
681 Life's Vehicle deny'd, the Lobster dies,
682 And dizzy Shades enwrap his horny Eyes.
683 For Fishes too must yield to chilling Death,
684 When ought shall stop the constant Flux of Breath.
685 They too like Earth-bred Animals respire;
686 Alternate Gusts maintain the vital Fire.
687 But long, e're spent with Toil, the Lobster strives,
688 Now vig'rous shoots away, or sudden dives,
689 Plies his broad Tail, and cuts the rolling Flood,
690 Oft heaves his Back, and shakes the pressing Load;
691 Now weary'd stays, and weaker Efforts tries,
692 Now pants despairing, and now bursting dies.
693 The Preke unmov'd will ne'er his Station quit,
694 Nor pressing Arms their close Embrace remit.
695 When stretch'd on Sands the Lobster breathless lies,
696 Then soon his folded Chains the Preke unties.
697 And, like the busy Infant at the Breast,
698 Sucks from the shelly Pipes the luscious Feast.
699 As the curst Wretch, in hardy Mischief prov'd,
700 Untouch'd with Pity, and with Guilt unmov'd,
701 Hid in the narrow Turn of winding Streets,
702 From late Debauch the gay Companion meets:
[Page 89]
703 He jocund stumbles on, nor ought designs,
704 Doz'd with the circling Pledge of unmixt Wines:
705 Unweening future Doom he reels along,
706 In fault'ring Accents hums a broken Song;
707 Fumes cloud the Brain, and sink the nodding Head,
708 And doubtful Feet in mazy Figures tread.
709 When sudden starting from his guilty Shades,
710 The Thief behind with hardy Grasp invades,
711 Back pulls him down, and gives the gushing Wound;
712 He groaning falls, and dying bites the Ground.
713 With Hast the Villain, fearful of Delay,
714 Strips the warm Dead, and bears the Spoils away.
715 Thus when the Lobster, lull'd by murm'ring Seas,
716 Clings to the Rock reclin'd in thoughtless Ease,
717 Unseen the wily Preke impetuous springs,
718 And all his branching Arms around the Captive flings.
719 These, of all Kinds that curl the wrinkled Waves,
720 That press the Sands, or hide in dropping Caves,
721 Impartial Foes, as if they Kindness meant,
722 By mutual Hate each others Wrongs resent.
723 Successive Deaths the fatal Circle tread,
724 Attend the Victor, and avenge the Dead.
725 Of Fishes some with venom'd Bane are stor'd,
726 Their hated Mouths the noxious Secret hoard.
[Page 90]
727 The deadly Juice drops in the wounded Part,
728 Enflames the whole, and mocks the healing Art.
729 Him most the Fishers dread, in hideous Form
730 And Name agreeing with that reptile Worm,
731 Whose Sides a double Row of Legs display,
732 That print a thousand Footsteps on the Clay.
733 Like him the Sea-born Monster o'er the Main
734 With num'rous Feet rows on his waving Train.
735 One Touch of these will angry Blotches raise;
736 The blister'd Flesh it's redd'ning Wales displays.
737 As when the well-known Weed with pointed Leaf
738 Thro' unseen Wounds injects the stinging Grief,
739 In Spots around the scarlet Venom spreads,
740 And rising Pustules show their ruddy Heads;
741 So touch'd by them, we feel the burning Pains
742 Itch in the Skin, and tingle in the Veins.
743 In gawdy Show the various Rainbow prides,
744 But beauteous Look a secret Poyson hides,
745 A dreaded Foe to those who dive below,
746 Where on hard Beds the porous Spunges grow,
747 From it's lov'd Moisture bear the Heap away,
748 And bring the rancid Substance to the Day.
749 When the gay Shoals perceive the prying Guest,
750 Envious they throng, and all his Search molest;
[Page 91]
751 With venom'd Teeth th'encumber'd Wretch surround,
752 Bite ev'ry Part, and suck the pleasing Wound.
753 Tho' clog'd by whelming Waves he flouncing strives,
754 Flings round his Arms, and back the Wantons drives.
755 Oft struck they can't forego the tempting Food,
756 Such is their ardent Thirst of human Blood.
757 So when full Ears scarce hold the ripen'd Grains,
758 And of rude Gales the whisp'ring Field complains,
759 When Reapers pine with Toil and sultry Heat,
760 The buzzing Squadrons scent the grateful Sweat;
761 On ev'ry Part they light, roam busy round,
762 Tickle the Face, and raise the ruddy Wound.
763 The Peasant fans them off, but they again
764 Wanton return, and strike the itching Pain.
765 Boldly impertinent the Lab'rer vex,
766 Buz round his Eyes, and bask upon his Cheeks;
767 Nor will the restless Swarms their Sport forego,
768 Till dead they fall prest by the quicker Blow;
769 Or cloy'd with Pleasure wing their silent Way,
770 And shun the Cool of the declining Day.
771 The crawling Preke a deadly Juice contains,
772 Injected Poyson fires the wounded Veins.
773 Soft Cuttle-Fish, that stain the flowing Tide
774 With inky Streams, more dreaded Moisture hide.
[Page 92]
775 Nor small the Wound like that the Rainbow gives;
776 But raging Pain the glowing Member grieves.
777 From their curst Mouths the dropping Fires distill,
778 Enflame the Blood, and shed the spreading Ill.
779 The prickly Gudgeon, that alternate dwells.
780 In sandy Coverts, or in rocky Cells;
781 Fierce Scorpions, who their waving Volumes wreath,
782 Or vault above, or glide unseen beneath;
783 Weevers, whose March the tim'rous Shoals obey,
784 Divide their Ranks, and humbly give the Way;
785 The Swallow-Fish, that sports with equal Ease
786 Or poiz'd in Air, or born on grosser Seas;
787 The rav'nous Sea-Hog, and the prickly Hound,
788 Whose piercing Bristles multiply the Wound;
789 All venom'd Juice in hollow Tubes retain,
790 And, as they prick, inject the flowing Bane.
791 Sharp poison'd Darts the dreaded Fire-Flairs aid,
792 And hardy Sword-Fish wield the threat'ning Blade.
793 Nature and Time the growing Part produce,
794 Finish it's Length, and teach the murd'rous Use.
795 Nor burnish'd Steel, nor Plates of flaming Brass
796 In solid Work the fishy Snout surpass.
797 Struck with it's Point, the sounding Stone gives Way,
798 And shatter'd Rocks their secret Veins display.
[Page 93]
799 The Fire-Flair's Tail it's venom'd Shaft contains;
800 Nor Time nor Wast the pois'nous Treasure drains.
801 Murd'rous alike they ravage all the Sea,
802 First give the mortal Wound, then seize the Prey.
803 In this they differ; when the Sword-Fish dies,
804 Extinct with him the mould'ring Weapon lies.
805 Despis'd and harmless now, the worthless Bone
806 No longer boasts the Sword, but useless grown
807 Henceforth it's martial Nature must disown.
808 Not so the Fire-Flair's Dart; that still survives
809 The dying Fish, and in it's Venom lives.
810 Man killing Arts has too industrious sought,
811 And murd'rous Science to Perfection brought.
812 For guilty Hands design'd, the sooty Trade
813 On sounding Anvils shapes the temper'd Blade.
814 Revengeful Persians not with Wounds content
815 Mix cursed Herbs, and deadly Juice ferment.
816 Too curious Search Death's hidden Stores reveals,
817 How Fate in Plants and pois'nous Powder dwells.
818 But of all Ills, that Art from Nature steals,
819 That Seas produce, or Earth's dark Womb conceals,
820 None equal that the Ray-like Fire-Flair bears;
821 No dreaded Stroke, no killing wound like hers.
[Page 94]
822 All Things must yield; the dire Infection's such,
823 The solid Flint would moulder at the Touch.
824 When rising Shrubs their spreading Branches shoot,
825 Pride in their Leaves, or joy in rip'ning Fruit,
826 If with the Fire-Flair's Spear the Hand unkind
827 But grate the Root, or prick the tender Rind,
828 The Leaves shrink in, and all the Glories fade,
829 Rich Sap no more is thro' the Pipes convey'd;
830 No kind Supplies flow round the porous Stem,
831 Cast a bright Green, and swell the smiling Gem,
832 But killing Juices all the Fibres taint,
833 And tarnish'd Verdure tells the fatal Want.
834 Dry Stalks now rustle on the Ground reclin'd,
835 Where Shades once trembled at the wanton Wind.
836 Circe, who all the secret Poisons knew,
837 Or wash'd by Seas, or nourish'd by the Dew,
838 Midst all the deadly Treasures of her Art
839 Most valu'd kept the Fire-Flair's venom'd Dart.
840 To it's long taper Shaft the fishy Spoil
841 The Goddess joyns, and fits for martial Toil.
842 On her lov'd Son, whom in a conscious Grot
843 Wand'ring from Troy the Grecian Chief begot,
844 Circe the Prize, the fatal Gift bestows,
845 Describes it's Use, and the hid Venom shows.
[Page 95]
846 He sought his Sire, till led by doubtful Fame
847 To rocky Coasts of Ithaca he came.
848 Here on his Father's Goats with youthful Pride
849 His fatal Spear the wanton Warrior try'd;
850 Around the Plain contagious Slaughters made,
851 And on rank Heaps the bearded Victims laid.
852 While careless he the pleasing Sport pursues,
853 The flying Herdsmen tell th' unwelcome News
854 The Chief incens'd recalls his youthful Hast,
855 To seize the Robber, and prevent the Wast.
856 But with blind Rage the Parricide possest
857 Assaults his Sire, and wounds his aged Breast.
858 Thro' boiling Veins the glowing Poisons roll,
859 And with dire Pains expell the ling'ring Soul.
860 Thus He, who dar'd the Dangers of the Main,
861 While Surges roll'd, and Tempests rag'd in vain,
862 His fated End in Sea-bred Venom found,
863 And from the Fire-Flair's Dart receiv'd his mortal Wound.
864 Vast Tunnies o'er the watry Surface sweep,
865 And the fierce Sword-Fish rolls the calmer Deep.
866 Tho' swift their Pace, tho' Fate attends their Strokes,
867 A worthless Fly the mighty Fish provokes.
[Page 96]
868 When the curst Dog begins the sultry Days,
869 And fev'rish Vapours taint the kinder Rays,
870 Then fearless of the Waves the Ocean-Breez
871 Broods on the Waters, and infests the Seas.
872 Beneath the shelt'ring Fin the Insects hide,
873 And goad with pois'nous Sting the tender Side.
874 Vext with the puny Foe the Tunnies leap,
875 Flounce on the Stream, and toss the mantling Deep,
876 Ride o'er the foaming Seas, with Torture rave,
877 Bound into Air, and dash the smoking Wave.
878 Oft with imprudent Hast they fly the Main,
879 And seek in Death a kind Release from Pain,
880 Vault on some Ship, or to the Shores repair,
881 And gasp away their hated Lives in Air.
882 So when from reeking Vales Autumnal Days
883 Sulphureous Steams, and ranker Vapours raise,
884 With circling Tail, and wild distorted Eyes
885 Thro' rustling Brakes the madded Heifer flies,
886 With sounding Hoof the heathy Common beats,
887 While far behind the hollowing Peasant sweats.
888 Driv'n by the Pain, when the fierce Gad-Bee strikes,
889 Nor Fence of twisted Hedge, nor slimy Dikes
890 Retain the Beast; but o'er the shelving Steep
891 And clotty Ridge she takes the doubtful Leap.
[Page 97]
892 Nor breezy Caves, nor Meads invite her Stay,
893 Tho' Banks obstruct, and Rivers cross the Way.
894 She fords the Stream, and climbs the rising Mound;
895 While distant Hills with bellowing Kine resound.
896 Dolphins, by all the liquid Realms rever'd,
897 Command the Seas, and rule the floating Herd.
898 The willing Tribes their native Lord obey,
899 Confess his Pow'r, and own the rightful Sway.
900 They ev'ry Kind in beauteous Form excell;
901 And awful Looks the true-born Monarch tell.
902 None can in Force with furious Dolphins vie,
903 Or the strong Fin with equal Vigour ply.
904 Dolphins as swift their rapid Course pursue,
905 As the wing'd Steel springs from the twanging Yew.
906 Fires sparkle in their Eyes, and gleaming Rays
907 Brighten the wat'ry Shade, and clear the gloomy Ways.
908 When Fishes with vain Hopes their trembling Heads
909 Or wrap in Slime, or roll in sandy Beds,
910 Midst the dark Shade they form a sudden Day,
911 And all the Secrets of the Depth survey.
912 When Lions roar, the Beasts with Terrour hear,
913 And by their Silence own their passive Fear.
914 Birds distant view, when Eagles soar on high,
915 And humbly give the Freedom of the Sky.
[Page 98]
916 When flaggy Wings the glaring Dragon bear
917 In shining Tracks, and taint the gilded Air,
918 Silent below the meaner Serpent creeps,
919 Nor dares to hiss, but hides in weedy Heaps.
920 And thus in Pow'r unrival'd Dolphins reign
921 O'er the unbounded Empire of the Main.
922 While o'er the Floods the wanton Dolphin rolls,
923 All give the Sea, and drive their mingled Shoals.
924 With fearful Hast their thronging Heaps they raise,
925 Nor on their dreaded Monarch steady gaze.
926 Passive they turn their Eyes; with servile Fear
927 His furious Bounds, and distant Puffings hear.
928 But when the Sov'rain hungry seeks his Prey,
929 Then frighted Numbers crowd the narrow Sea.
930 From the known Tyrant all the meaner Slaves
931 Throng to the Friths, and nestle in the Caves.
932 He in crude Feasts his purpled Jaws embrues;
933 From the mixt Heaps will noblest Captives chuse,
934 Let go the tastless Prey, and vulgar Treats refuse.
935 But hardy Troops are found, and they alone
936 That brave the Dolphin, and his Sway disown;
937 With equal Scorn the Tyrant's Wrong repay,
938 Nor passive will the lawless Force obey:
[Page 99]
939 Amies their Name; no pointed Spikes they bear,
940 Nor wield the Sword, nor dart the pois'nous Spear;
941 But close-set Teeth their vaulted Mouth surround,
942 That ready strike, and give the certain Wound.
943 With these fierce Amies, for the Fight prepar'd,
944 Engage their Monarch, nor his Threats 'regard.
945 When wanton Dolphins from their Fellows stray,
946 And the lone Wand'rers take their private Way,
947 Amies observe, and spread the pleasing News;
948 None dread the Danger, or the Toil excuse:
949 With firm Consent the Summons all obey,
950 Press to the Charge, and throng the straighten'd Way.
951 So when the Hopes of Fame, and hostile Spoils
952 To glorious Hazard push th' embattled Files.
953 Resolv'd they move, and all the Danger court,
954 Scale the high Wall, and raze the batter'd Fort:
955 War to the truly brave is only Sport.
956 Awhile the Dolphin, tho' unnumber'd Foes
957 Ally'd to One united Force oppose,
958 Nor royal Birth, nor ancient Fame forgets;
959 But mocks th' Invaders, and their Onset meets:
960 Feeds with Revenge, and tasts the double Sweets
961 Of slaughter'd Rebels, and of grateful Treats.
[Page 100]
962 But when around the rallying Troops appear,
963 Rush in the Front, and thicken in the Rear,
964 War's doubtful Toils the finny Chief engage,
965 Rebellion worthy all the Monarch's Rage.
966 Fearless of Danger they at once surround
967 The Princely Fish, and all the Dolphin wound.
968 With Rage inveterate the restless Shoals
969 Make at his Head, and on his azure Jowls
970 Remorseless fasten; on his Back they ride,
971 Hang on his Gills, and tear his bleeding Side.
972 Some glide beneath, others behind him press,
973 Burden the Tail, and all the Fish distress.
974 He lab'ring puffs, tho' weaken'd with his Wounds
975 Yet vig'rous shoots, and all the Ocean rounds.
976 Vext with Disgrace, and Sense of various Pain
977 He meditates Revenge; with proud Disdain
978 Now swift as sunny Gleams the Dolphin leaps
979 Thro' flying Mists, and o'er the Surface sweeps.
980 Like Lightning now he gilds the Depths below,
981 Where silent Waves, and stiller Waters flow.
982 Nor mirksom Shades below, nor upper Seas,
983 Remove the Foes, nor give the Sov'rain Ease.
984 They still unmov'd their fasten'd Hold retain,
985 Drive with their Guide, and round the troubled Main.
[Page 101]
986 Where're he moves, unwelcome they attend,
987 And born by him, with him as swift descend
988 To lowest Seas, as swift again pursue
989 Repeated Tracks, and clearer Day review.
990 Thus joyn'd they all one monstrous Fish appear,
991 And to known Shapes no certain Likeness bear.
992 Fishers amaz'd long fix their steady Eyes,
993 While blended Kinds their real Form disguise.
994 As when the stagnate Blood corrupting breeds
995 The putrid Sore, and glowing Ulcer feeds;
996 The dusky Leeches drain the noisome Food,
997 And give new Motion to the clotted Blood;
998 Curl up their Backs, and swell their bloated Sides,
999 And by strong Suction force the streaming Tides;
1000 But when the long continu'd Pleasures cloy,
1001 Senseless they fall, and dizzy with the Joy.
1002 Thus Amies hung around the Dolphin twine,
1003 Rivet their Teeth, nor will the Part resign.
1004 When fed the weary Dolphin they release;
1005 Disperse themselves, and drive along the Seas.
1006 The Royal Fish, from hostile Numbers freed,
1007 Resumes his Vigour, and exerts his Speed,
1008 Furious he dashes round the broken Waves,
1009 Devours whole Shoals and grinds the gasping Slaves.
[Page 102]
1010 The reeking Blood shines on the redden'd Ooze,
1011 And blushing Waves their smiling Azure lose.
1012 Flight or Resistance now no longer save,
1013 But in Return they feel the Wounds they gave.
1014 When prowling Troops of Wolves some wand'ring Deer
1015 In num'rous Concert hunt; she wing'd with Fear
1016 Skims o'er the Dale, and from the Mountain bounds;
1017 With braying Plaints the vocal Wood resounds.
1018 The furious Wolves with more than equal Pace
1019 Reach to the Wound, and gain upon the Chace;
1020 From her fat Sides the reeking Morsels tear,
1021 Bear on the Haunch, and flea the living Deer.
1022 Their harmless Prey securely they destroy,
1023 And unaveng'd the guilty Meal enjoy.
1024 Void of Remorse, and insolent with Pride
1025 Laugh at her Groans, and all her Pains deride.
1026 Not so the Dolphin's Foes unhurt retreat;
1027 A just Revenge the daring Rebels meet,
1028 Their former Insults of the Monarch grieve,
1029 And Pains for Pains, and Wounds for Wounds receive.
1030 Dolphins in Death their royal Birth regard,
1031 Act like themselves, and for the Hour prepar'd,
[Page 103]
1032 Their Doom expecting they intrepid wait,
1033 Ev'n then are careful to preserve their State;
1034 Fate's Summons with Indifference obey,
1035 But fly the Depths, and leave the wider Sea.
1036 Lest meaner Fish the floating Carkass meet,
1037 And with rude Scorn their lifeless Sov'rain treat.
1038 To wavy Sands they silently retire,
1039 Lie there unknown, and unobserv'd expire.
1040 On the moist Bed recline their sickly Head,
1041 Where no base Fish insults the royal Dead;
1042 And hope that grateful Man with pious Hand
1043 Will give his Friend the Burial of the Sand:
1044 At least the Waters and returning Tide
1045 Will in their wracky Heaps the princely Relicks hide.
1046 Living they rule, and dying leave the Main;
1047 No base-bred Foes their injur'd Corps profane.
1048 Greatness of Soul in latest Hours appears:
1049 Careless of Life the thoughtless Hero fears,
1050 Lest ought that's less'ning, or that's mean at last
1051 A sullying Stain on former Glories cast.
1052 And Dolphins thus in Death we must admire
1053 Just to themselves; their Conduct is entire.
1054 Careful t' assert their Honour, and maintain
1055 Their former Port, the Dolphins dying reign.
[Page 104]
1056 Barbels, unlike the rest, are just and mild,
1057 No Fish they harm, by them no Seas are spoil'd.
1058 Nor on their own, nor diff'rent Kinds they prey,
1059 But equal Laws of common Right obey.
1060 Undreaded they with guiltless Pleasure feed
1061 On fat'ning Slime, or bite the sea-grown Weed.
1062 Each licks his Mate; by Love the Barbel lives,
1063 And the dear Kiss alternate Pleasure gives.
1064 The Good and Just are Heaven's peculiar Care:
1065 All rav'nous Kinds the sacred Barbel spare;
1066 Nor will tho' hungry seize the gentle Fry,
1067 But give the Look, and pitying pass them by.
1068 Honour's just Meed, and due Rewards attend
1069 The brave good Man, who scorns the selfish End,
1070 Will on no Rights by lawless Pow'r intrude,
1071 But to his own prefers the publick Good.
1072 Ev'n stormy Seas the juster Kinds revere,
1073 And Fishes some Respect to Virtue bear.
1074 But All besides, voracious and unjust,
1075 Obey their Passions, and indulge their Lust.
1076 When Hunger calls, they roam abroad for Food,
1077 Pursue the weaker, by the strong pursu'd.
1078 All the Night long they constant Watches keep,
1079 Nor one unguarded Moment give to Sleep.
[Page 105]
1080 Scaro's alone their folded Eye-lids close
1081 In grateful Intervals of soft Repose.
1082 In some sequester'd Cell remov'd from Sight,
1083 They sleep away the Dangers of the Night.
1084 The rest all wakeful dread the dire Surprize;
1085 From midnight Fears the God of Slumber flies.
1086 Fondly we blame the Rage of warring Fish,
1087 Who urg'd by Hunger must supply the Wish;
1088 When cruel Men, to whom their ready Food
1089 Kind Earth affords, yet thirst for human Blood.
1090 Peace, griev'd by Man, to brighter Regions fled,
1091 And angry Mars contending Nations led.
1092 Ambitious Youths with Thirst of Glory fir'd
1093 The proud Deformity of Scars admir'd.
1094 Pow'r uncontroll'd maintain'd the wrongful Cause,
1095 Nor fear'd the weaker Force of silent Laws.
1096 Nor would ungovern'd Rage the Temples spare;
1097 But ev'n the Gods forgot their wonted Care.
1098 The hoary Priest oft while he suppliant pray'd,
1099 On his own Altar was a Victim made.
1100 Bold Sacrilege laid hallow'd Buildings wast,
1101 And in vile Heaps the sacred Rubbish cast.
1102 In circling Wreaths to Heav'n their impious Fires
1103 Boldly went up, and roll'd their guilty Spires.
[Page 106]
1104 Statues deform'd lay headless on the Ground,
1105 None knew what God the dubious Image own'd.
1106 At length soft Peace look'd back; the Troubles ceast,
1107 And pitying Heaven gave the Kingdoms Rest.
1108 From good Æneas sprung, the Cesars came
1109 To sooth the World, and quench the spreading Flame.
1110 Yet restless Discord would unconquer'd strive
1111 The dying Sparks of Fury to revive.
1112 The proud Iberian, and the warlike Gaul
1113 Repin'd at Ease, and heard Bellona's Call.
1114 Oft did the Rhine polluted Currents mourn,
1115 And wash the Stains from his discolour'd Urn.
1116 Oft from his Reeds old Ister silent gaz'd,
1117 And saw his Banks by slaughter'd Legions rais'd.
1118 Till you, blest Pair, so kinder Heav'n decreed,
1119 Peace unallay'd restor'd, and groaning Nations freed.
1120 Now settled Peace broods on the smiling Vales,
1121 And steady Justice holds th' impartial Scales.
1122 Astrea comes, the Goddess comes again,
1123 And from injurious Rapin guards the Plain.
1124 Plenty around her various Mantle spreads,
1125 O'er flow'ry Pastures, and unforrag'd Meads.
1126 The God of Sleep, freed from the noisy Dread,
1127 On ev'ry Bank inclines his drowzy Head.
[Page 107]
1128 Gay painted Dreams skim o'er the silent Plain,
1129 And kindly hover on the slumb'ring Swain.
1130 The joyous Sun smiles on the calmer Day,
1131 And little Loves in ev'ry Corner play.
1132 May the Good Gods these Halcyon Days prolong,
1133 Give Rust to Arms, and Leisure to the Song.
1134 May, thro' the Round of long successive Years,
1135 Continu'd Peace prevent our future Fears.
1136 Now suppliant Right fears no disgustful Frown
1137 Or from th' Imperial Sire, or Royal Son.
1138 Now humble Merit meets a just Reward,
1139 Nor will the Court disdain the peaceful Bard.
1140 May Jove, and those bright Messengers of Fate,
1141 That throng his Throne, and on the Godhead wait,
1142 May all indulgent guard the Royal Pair,
1143 The World's great Monarch, and the blooming Heir.
1144 Our Wishes must succeed, our Pray'rs are heard,
1145 If Piety deserves a just Reward.
1146 The Heav'nly Pow'rs will look propitious down,
1147 By sure Succession fix th' establish'd Throne,
1148 Preserve th' Immortal Sire, and aid the Godlike Son.
